you could put this in the first commit? Oh well
it's intentionally put in this commit because this is the first unit tests that REQUIRES 1.14.0
Acknowledged
Open Group documentation for mkstemp() says portable applications should use exactly 6 'X' characters. I'm not sure if it matters in our environment.

I don't think it matters, but it's trivial to fix.

Fixed.
```#include <string>```
Done
```#include <boost/system/error_code.hpp>```
Done
```#include <array>```
Done
Should the additional 6 bytes of the payload be verified to make sure they aren't garbage? Or at least verify buffer[10] = '\0'?
We already check that out == 10.  in theory if it wrote the buffer that it had access to, but didn't return it, would it be a problem?

From reading the EXPECT_THAT() documentation it is not clear to me that it does verify the count is exactly the same between the two items.

So, if (out == 11), and (buffer.data == "teststringX"), would EXPECT_THAT still report an error here?

On a read here I wouldn't expect any more to be read than the file actually contains. I wouldn't want garbage to be returned on the read even if the buffer had room for it.

> From reading the EXPECT_THAT() documentation it is not clear to me that it does verify the count is exactly the same between the two items.
> 
> So, if (out == 11), and (buffer.data == "teststringX"), would EXPECT_THAT still report an error here?
> 
> On a read here I wouldn't expect any more to be read than the file actually contains. I wouldn't want garbage to be returned on the read even if the buffer had room for it.

While I don't necessarily agree, i'm not going to argue over something that's trivially fixed.  I've added a check to ensure that the array ends with a null terminator to both this and line 93.
Same question here, should the additional 6 bytes of the payload be verified to make sure they aren't garbage? (Expect '\0'?)
Lets discuss above.  This will have the same conclusion.
Acknowledged

Why do we have to use pipe? 
Why can't we use std::ofstream ?

Because the intent of this test is to test that pipes work.

ofstream would test that files work, which is fine (we already have tests that cover those cases) files support getting the size, so it wouldn't be a representative test of something that is being built on the fly.

In another comment 
" Ed Tanous 

the pipe code has been entirely removed. I'll add it back at such time as we need it."
Should we confirm this is null terminated?
Why?  There's no expectation that this is null terminated.  string_views are not null terminated.
Since this was being read into a std::array I was expecting it would be null terminated.

..... I'm missing something.  Why are std::arrays guaranteed to be null terminated?  To my knowledge, there's no implied or explicit requirement that a std::array be null terminated.  If there was, it would likely lead to problems with buffers that contained null terminators.

I see your point and I agree with you. I was trying to make the FileBody interface something it is not.

So maybe instead a check that EXPECT_EQ(out, 10) would address my concern?
ElementsAre already checks size matches the array on the other side, otherwise the elements wouldn't match (there would be an extra).
Ahh, I didn't realize that. So I'm good with the test being done here.

Because you seem interested, here's the code that implements the size check.  its open source, so no need to worry about the documentation:

https://github.com/google/googletest/blob/456574145cf71a5375777cab58453acfd92a920b/googlemock/include/gmock/gmock-matchers.h#L3463
Done
Thank you for the link!
Looks good to me.
pipe accepts int[2], not int*

but anyway it is going to decay to a pointer to the first element. I did not see any compilation error if we tried with int pipefd[1] = {0}; That means array declaration doesn't make any difference for compilation. So std::array will be a simpler replacement, and if it removes the clang warning the code looks neater.

> but anyway it is going to decay to a pointer to the first element.

pipe() doesn't accept an array pointer, it accepts a C array of size two.

> I did not see any compilation error if we tried with int pipefd[1] = {0}

?  Why would an int array of size 1 help us here.  We need an int array of size 2?  Also note, this wasn't a compilation error with gcc, but tidy.  You're right, gcc will compile this code just fine.

>; That means array declaration doesn't make any difference for compilation. So std::array will be a simpler replacement, and if it removes the clang warning the code looks neater.

Please just run the full suite of CI tests on it, and tell me what you tested.  When I tested all the variations, I wasn't able to get std::array to both call correctly into pipe() AND pass clang/gcc/tidy warnings.  If you have something that does, please let me know what it is, but I had previously tried all the variations you suggested.

Ideally just stack a patch on top of this one;  If it passes CI, I can just squash it in.
the pipe code has been entirely removed.  I'll add it back at such time as we need it.
